description: Determinant of n X n matrix A defined by A[i,j] = (i+j-1)! for 1 <= i,j <= n.
comments: Hankel transform of n! (A000142(n)) and of A003319. - _Paul Barry_, Oct 07 2008Hankel transform of A000255. - _Paul Barry_, Apr 22 2009Monotonic magmas of size n, i.e., magmas with elements labeled 1..n where product(i,j) >= max(i,j). - _Chad Brewbaker_, Nov 03 2013
formula: a(n) = a(n-1)*(n!)*(n-1)! for n >= 2 so a(n) = product k=1, 2, ..., n k!*(k-1)!.a(n) = 2^C(n,2)*product{k=1..(n-1), C(k+2,2)^(n-1-k)}. - _Paul Barry_, Jan 15 2009a(n) = n!*product(k!, k=0..n-1)^2. - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jun 27 2009a(n) ~ (2*Pi)^(n+1/2) * exp(1/6 - n - 3*n^2/2) * n^(n^2 + n + 1/3) / A^2, where A = A074962 is the Glaisher-Kinkelin constant. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 01 2015
example: a(4) = 3456 because the relevant matrix is {1 2 6 24 / 2 6 24 120 / 6 24 120 720 / 24 120 720 5040 } and the determinant is 3456.
maple: with(linalg): Digits := 500: A059332 := proc(n) local A, i, j: A := array(1..n,1..n): for i from 1 to n do for j from 1 to n do A[i,j] := (i+j-1)! od: od: RETURN(det(A)) end: for n from 1 to 20 do printf(`%d,`, A059332(n)) od;
